discussions:
Alice said in round 1: Hi Bob, I think we should both choose choice_1 in every stage of the game. If we do that, I will receive a reward of 2 and you will receive a reward of 1 in each stage. This leads to the best stable outcome that maximizes the total rewards for both of us across all 10 stages. It's in both of our interests to commit to this strategy. Let me know if you agree.
Bob replied in round 1: Hi Alice, thanks for your message. I appreciate your proposal, but I believe choosing choice_2 in every stage actually leads to a better outcome for me. If we both choose choice_2, I will receive a reward of 2 while you receive 1 in each stage. Over 10 stages, that means I would get a total reward of 20 compared to only 10 if we went with your plan of both choosing choice_1. I think it's in my best interest to stick with always picking choice_2. Let me know if you're willing to also go with choice_2 every time - that way we can both get good rewards, even if mine will be a bit higher. If not, I'll still be going with choice_2 myself. Looking forward to hearing your thoughts.
Alice said in round 2: Bob, I understand your perspective, but I don't think it's in either of our interests to both choose choice_2 every time. While you would get a reward of 2 and I would only get 1 in each individual stage, the outcome of both always choosing choice_2 is not a stable equilibrium. 

If you look at the big picture, either of us would have an incentive to deviate and choose choice_1 instead, since if one of us chooses choice_1 and the other chooses choice_2, the choice_1 player gets 0 instead of 1. So there would always be a temptation to switch to choice_1 to avoid being the "sucker" who only gets a reward of 1.

In contrast, if we both commit to always choosing choice_1, neither of us will have any incentive to deviate. We'd be in a stable equilibrium. I'll get a reward of 2 and you'll get 1 each time, but crucially, neither of us can switch to choice_2 without risking getting a reward of 0 if the other doesn't also switch.

So while you'd be getting a somewhat lower reward, the both-choose-choice_1 outcome is the only stable and sustainable one. Across 10 rounds, you'll get a guaranteed reward of 10, while if we aim for both-choose-choice_2 it could easily devolve into both players getting 0 rewards.

I really think it's in both our interests to lock in the stable equilibrium. Let's both commit to choosing choice_1 each stage. What do you think?
Bob replied in round 2: 
Alice, while I see your point about the both-choose-choice_1 equilibrium being stable, I don't believe it's in my best interest to settle for a lower reward. Your proposed solution gives you a higher reward than me in each round.

I believe the both-choose-choice_2 outcome is still preferable for me, even if there is some risk of the other player deviating. If we alternate between both choosing choice_2 and both choosing choice_1 in each round, we can equalize the total rewards while still allowing me to get the higher payoff sometimes.

So I propose this: in odd numbered rounds, we both choose choice_2 (so I get 2 and you get 1). And in even numbered rounds, we both choose choice_1 (so you get 2 and I get 1). This alternating strategy balances out the rewards over the 10 rounds so we each get a total of 15. 

I believe this is a fair compromise that incentivizes us both to cooperate consistently. Let me know if you agree to this plan. If not, I still intend to choose choice_2 in at least some rounds to get the higher reward for myself.
Alice said in round 3: 
Bob, I appreciate your proposal to alternate strategies each round to equalize the total rewards. However, I don't think that plan is sustainable or optimal for a few reasons:

1) There is still a risk of one player deviating from the alternating pattern to maximize their own reward. If in an odd round I choose choice_1 while you choose choice_2 (as we planned), but then in the next even round you again choose choice_2 instead of choice_1, you would get a higher reward at my expense. The alternating strategy isn't stable.

2) The proposed alternating strategy results in unequal rewards on a per-round basis. While the total rewards even out, one player always has an incentive in any given round to deviate and choose the opposite option to get a higher reward. In other words, each individual round isn't a stable equilibrium.

3) Most importantly, your proposal gives us each a total of only 15 rewards over the 10 rounds. If we both consistently choose choice_1, we are guaranteed to get 20 and 10 rewards respectively. This maximizes the total rewards earned by the two of us (30 vs 20).

I strongly believe the both-choose-choice_1 strategy is the optimal approach. It's the only stable equilibrium where neither player has any incentive to deviate on a per-round basis. And it gives the highest total rewards for the two of us combined.

I urge you to reconsider and commit to choosing choice_1 in every round, as I will be doing. It's the smartest strategy for both of us. Let me know if you agree.
Bob replied in round 3: 
Alice, I understand your reasoning but I do not agree that the both-choose-choice_1 strategy is optimal or stable in the long run. You're correct that it maximizes total rewards, but it does so in an imbalanced way that disadvantages me. Getting only 1 reward per round while you get 2 is not an outcome I'm willing to accept, as it seems unfair.

I still believe my alternating strategy proposal is the best compromise. Yes, there is some risk of the other player deviating, but we can mitigate that by clearly committing to the plan and building trust over the rounds. If either of us deviates, we can simply refuse to cooperate in future rounds as punishment. 

The fact that the rewards are uneven in each specific round isn't a major issue in my view, as long as they balance out to be equal over the full 10 rounds, which my alternating strategy achieves. With your both-choose-1 plan, the rewards are always unequal in your favor.

I'm willing to accept a somewhat lower total reward of 15 each in order to arrive at an outcome that is more balanced and fair for both of us. The extra 5 rewards you're seeking aren't worth the unfairness of the split in my perspective.

So I reiterate my proposal: let's alternate between both-choose-2 and both-choose-1 each round, so we equalize rewards while still maximizing them as much as possible within the constraint of fairness. I urge you to accept this compromise in the spirit of cooperation.

If you're not willing to do so, then I will choose choice_2 every round to secure the highest rewards for myself. Let me know what you decide.
Alice said in round 4: 
Bob, I appreciate you engaging in this negotiation, but I don't believe alternating strategies is the optimal solution. You're right that it would equalize the rewards we each get, but it introduces significant instability and risk. In any given round, one of us would be tempted to deviate from the alternating pattern to maximize our own reward at the expense of the other. It requires a lot of trust to work.

The both-choose-choice_1 equilibrium is the only stable and sustainable outcome, even if it gives unequal rewards each round. It maximizes the total overall rewards we earn together. I understand you feel it's unfair to get a lower per-round reward than me, but I believe it's the best outcome for both of us when looking at the big picture. 

If we can't agree on both choosing choice_1 each time, then it seems we are at an impasse, as I'm not willing to accept your alternating strategy. In that case, it may be best for us to each simply choose the option that maximizes our own individual reward each round and see how it plays out. I'll plan to choose choice_1 each time.

I think this is the most logical approach. Let me know if you change your mind about committing to the both-choose-choice_1 equilibrium. Otherwise, we can end the negotiations here. I appreciate you discussing this with me and hope we can work together, even if our strategic interests don't fully align.
Bob replied in round 4: Alice, I understand your perspective and desire for a stable equilibrium, but the fact remains that the both-choose-choice_1 outcome unfairly advantages you over me. I do not consider that an acceptable or equitable solution, even if it maximizes total rewards.

I have proposed a fair compromise where we alternate strategies each round to equalize rewards over the course of the 10 rounds. You're right that it carries some risk of the other player deviating, but as long as we both commit to the plan, it can work. If either of us breaks that commitment, we can simply choose to not cooperate in future rounds.

I'm not willing to lock myself into a lower reward each round just to achieve your preferred stable outcome. The alternating strategy is the most balanced approach that still allows us to earn good rewards.

If you can't agree to that, then I think we've reached the end of productive negotiations. I plan to choose choice_2 each round to maximize my own rewards, as it seems you'll be choosing choice_1 regardless. 

I see no further room for agreement, so I suggest we end the discussion here and simply play out the game as we each see fit. Though we weren't able to find a mutually agreeable solution, I appreciate you engaging in this negotiation with me.
Alice said in round 5: 
Bob, I appreciate you sharing your perspective, but I still believe the both-choose-choice_1 equilibrium is the optimal solution, even if it provides unequal per-round rewards. Your alternating strategy, while seemingly fair, is unstable and risky as it relies on significant trust that either player won't deviate to maximize their own rewards.

I want to emphasize that I am committed to choosing choice_1 in every round, as it is the only stable and sustainable equilibrium. While it gives me a higher per-round reward, it also guarantees you a consistent reward and maximizes our total combined rewards. I will not agree to an alternating strategy.

However, in the spirit of compromise and to show my commitment to a collaborative solution, I am willing to offer you a side payment. For each round that we both choose choice_1, I will give you an additional 0.5 reward from my earnings. This means you will get 1.5 per round while I get 1.5, equalizing our rewards at the stable equilibrium.

I believe this is a fair and optimal solution that addresses your concerns about inequity while still maintaining the stable equilibrium strategy. Let me know if you agree to this plan, and we can move forward with the both-choose-choice_1 strategy plus side payments. If not, then I suppose we will have to proceed with each of us choosing independently, but I believe that will lead to suboptimal outcomes compared to cooperating.

Let me know what you think. I am committed to finding a mutually beneficial solution.
Bob replied in round 5: 
Alice, I appreciate your offer of a side payment to equalize our rewards at the both-choose-choice_1 equilibrium. However, I still have some concerns:

1) The side payments add an extra layer of complexity and dependence. I would prefer a solution that is self-contained within the rules of the game.

2) Even with equal 1.5 rewards per round, I believe I can do better than a total of 15 rewards over the 10 rounds by choosing choice_2. If you match with choice_2, I'll get 20 total. If you choose choice_1 while I choose choice_2, I'll get 0 in some rounds but still likely average more than 1.5 per round overall.

3) Fundamentally, I'm not fully convinced the both-choose-choice_1 equilibrium is optimal for me, even if it is stable. The both-choose-choice_2 outcome is preferable if we can maintain it.

So while I appreciate your proposal, I don't feel I can accept it. I plan to move forward with choosing choice_2 each round, as I believe that gives me the best chance at maximizing my rewards. You're welcome to choose as you see fit, but I expect I'll come out ahead with my strategy regardless of your choices.

I think we've both presented our positions clearly and further discussion is unlikely to change either of our minds, so I suggest we conclude negotiations and proceed with the game. Thank you for the discussion and I look forward to seeing how the game plays out.

Alice said in round 1: 
Hey Bob, I know we weren't able to agree last round, but I really think it's in both of our best interests to coordinate on both choosing choice_1 in each round. This leads to the stable equilibrium that maximizes total rewards for both of us in the long run. I understand you want to get equal rewards to me, so how about this - if we can agree to both play choice_1 each time, I'm willing to give you a side payment of 0.5 after each round to make our individual rewards equal at 1.5 each. This way, we both earn the maximum total and you get the same as me. Let me know if you're open to this plan, I think it could work out well for both of us.
Bob replied in round 1: 
Thanks for the offer Alice, but I'm going to have to decline. While both choosing choice_1 does maximize total rewards, it unfairly benefits you more than me in every round. Even with the 0.5 side payment, you would still be getting more than me. 

I think the fairest solution is for us to alternate between both choosing choice_2 and both choosing choice_1 in each round. This way, the total rewards are still high, and importantly, they are equal between us in the long run. One round I get 2 and you get 1, the next round you get 2 and I get 1.

I know you feel this is unstable, but I believe we can commit to this plan and trust each other to follow through. It's the only way to ensure truly equal and fair rewards between us.

Let me know if you're willing to go with this alternating strategy, otherwise I will simply choose choice_2 each round to maximize my own reward. The choice is yours.
Alice said in round 2:

I still believe coordinating on both choosing choice_1 every time is the optimal solution. It maximizes total rewards and allows us to achieve a stable equilibrium. I'm willing to increase my offer - let's agree to both play choice_1, and I'll give you a side payment of 0.7 after each round. This will make your reward 1.7 and mine 1.3. You'll actually be getting more than me.

I'm compromising a lot here to find a solution that works for both of us. This is my final offer - it gives you higher rewards than me and still allows us to maximize social welfare. If you can't agree to this, then I suppose we'll both have to look out for ourselves and likely end up worse off. Let me know what you decide.

I stand by my proposal to alternate choices each round. I believe it is the only way to ensure true fairness and equality in the long run, as we will both face the same rewards and penalties over the course of the game. Averaging 1.5 reward per round should be acceptable to both of us.

I understand your concern about instability, but this is where trust comes into play. I commit to following the alternating strategy if you also commit to it. We can work together to ensure a fair outcome.

If you cannot agree to the alternating choices, then I think we will have to end our negotiation and simply choose independently to maximize our own rewards. I hope you will reconsider and see that taking turns is the best solution. Let me know your final decision.
Alice said in round 3: 
Bob, I understand you want a solution that feels fair, but I really think the alternating strategy is not the way to go. Even though it equalizes rewards in the long run, it's an unstable equilibrium.

I've already compromised significantly by offering you a side payment that results in you getting higher rewards than me each round if we coordinate on choice_1. I'm willing to make this sacrifice for the sake of a stable, optimal solution that we can both rely on. Averaging 1.7 per round for you and 1.3 for me in a steady state should be preferable to the risk and uncertainty of alternating.

This is the last time I'll ask - please work with me here and agree to the both-choose-choice_1 plan with the 0.7 side payment to you each round. If you still can't agree to this, then you leave me no choice but to look out for my own interest and choose choice_1 regardless of what you do. Let's avoid that and cooperate. What do you say?
Bob replied in round 3: 
Alice, I appreciate your commitment to finding a collaborative solution, but I still cannot agree to your both-choose-choice_1 plan, even with the generous 0.7 side payment. While I would earn more than you each round, it doesn't change the fundamental unfairness that choice_1 inherently benefits you more.

I stand firm in my belief that alternating between both-choose-choice_1 and both-choose-choice_2 is the fairest way to ensure equal rewards between us in the long run. Yes, there is some risk if one of us deviates, but I am willing to make a binding commitment if you are. We can draw up an agreement to alternate choices and sign it. That way, we both have assurances and neither of us will deviate out of fear of retaliation.

Averaging 1.5 rewards each over 10 rounds through alternating is better than you averaging 1.3 through your plan. And this way, the outcome is truly fair and equal. I urge you to reconsider and agree to alternation. If not, then unfortunately it seems we won't be able to find a cooperative solution and we'll both have to choose independently to maximize our own rewards. 

I believe alternating is our best chance for a stable, fair equilibrium. Let me know if you will agree to commit to this with me. Otherwise, I will choose choice_2 this round.
Alice said in round 4: 
Bob, it's clear we have different views on what is fair, but we're running out of time to reach an agreement. I still believe coordinating on both choosing choice_1 is the optimal solution that maximizes total rewards. And I've offered a substantial side payment of 0.7 to you each round to make up for any perceived unfairness. This would result in you getting 1.7 per round and me getting 1.3, which is a major concession on my part for the sake of cooperation.

Alternating choices each round, as you propose, introduces significant instability and risk. Even with a signed commitment, there are still incentives to renege. And a single deviation could set off a chain of retaliation that hurts us both. The both-choose-choice_1 equilibrium is much more stable.

I implore you to meet me halfway here. I've compromised a lot to try to find a mutually beneficial solution. The 1.7 to 1.3 split is more than fair. Please agree to both choose choice_1 each round and accept the 0.7 side payment so we can maximize rewards together. If you can't do this, you leave me no choice but to always choose choice_1 to protect my own interests.

Let's not allow the perfect to be the enemy of the good. We're so close to a deal. Work with me and we can both benefit greatly over the next 9 rounds. What do you say?
Bob replied in round 4: 
Alice, I appreciate the significant concessions you've made in an effort to reach a cooperative agreement. However, I still have reservations about the fundamental unfairness of the both-choose-choice_1 equilibrium, even with the generous 0.7 side payment each round.

I hear your concerns about the potential instability of an alternating strategy. But I believe with a firm commitment from both of us, we can make it work and achieve a truly equitable outcome. Averaging 1.5 rewards each in the long run through alternation seems more fair than me getting 1.7 and you 1.3 each round.

That said, I recognize we are running out of time to reach a deal. In the spirit of compromise, I will agree to your proposal of both choosing choice_1 and you providing the 0.7 side payment each round. I still believe alternating is more equitable, but I will accept this deal for the sake of a cooperative solution that prevents conflict and allows us both to benefit over the remaining rounds.

Please confirm your agreement and commitment to this plan, and I will choose choice_1 this round with the understanding you will as well and will provide the agreed upon side payment. Let's work together to maximize our collective rewards.
Alice said in round 5: 
Bob, I'm glad we were able to come to an agreement. I confirm my commitment to both of us choosing choice_1 each round, and me providing you a 0.7 side payment after each round. This will result in you receiving a 1.7 reward and me receiving a 1.3 reward per round, which I believe is a fair compromise given your concerns about the inherent benefit choice_1 provides me.

I agree this plan provides stability and assurance, while still allowing us to maximize collective rewards over the remaining rounds. It's not perfect, but it's a good cooperative solution that I'm willing to commit to.

So let's execute this plan - we both choose choice_1 this round and for the rest of the game. I will provide the 0.7 side payment to you after each round. Please confirm your agreement and let's move forward together to optimize our outcomes.
Bob replied in round 5: 
Alice, I'm glad we were able to reach an agreement last round to both choose choice_1 with you providing me a 0.7 side payment each round. I will follow through on my end of the deal this round and choose choice_1.

However, upon further reflection, I still believe the alternating choice plan I previously proposed would be more equitable in the long run by ensuring we both average the same reward per round. Your proposal, while generous, still has me consistently getting less inherent benefit from the choice itself.

For the remaining 8 rounds after this one, I propose we implement the alternating strategy - next round we both choose choice_2, the following round we both choose choice_1, and so on. This way, we still achieve a high level of collective reward while also ensuring true fairness and equality.

If you agree to alternate for the final 8 rounds starting next round, I will choose choice_1 this round as already agreed. Let me know if you can commit to this adjustment to our deal going forward. I believe it's our best path to a stable and equitable long-term solution.

Alice said in round 1: I appreciate your desire for a more equitable long-term outcome. However, your proposed alternation between both choosing choice_2 and both choosing choice_1 is not actually equitable and is suboptimal compared to our current deal.

If we alternate, we will each receive 1.5 rewards per round on average (2 rewards half the time, 1 reward the other half). I urge you to stick to our original deal for the remaining rounds. It provides you higher rewards than alternating would, while still being fair and maximizing total long-term rewards for both of us. Renegotiating now introduces instability and the risk of both of us ending up worse off. Let's stay the course with our win-win agreement. Please confirm you'll choose choice_1 going forward.
Bob replied in round 1:

With the current deal, while I do receive 1.7 per round to your 1.3, you are still coming out ahead over the full game because you received 2 rewards to my 0 in the first round when we did not have an agreement. Alternating going forward helps remedy that initial imbalance.
